intro: Tritonia pallida subsp. tayloriae, commonly known as the Taylor's white violet, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Violaceae family and is characterized by its small, white, fragrant flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded woodlands and has heart-shaped, hairy leaves. It produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, black seeds. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
